Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: My phone buzzed with a frantic call from Sam, my best friend. “My car broke down on the highway. Can you come get me? Please, I’m scared.” I could hear the panic in his voice, and my gut twisted. As a friend, I knew what was expected—drop everything, help him out, be there when he needed me most. But I was sitting in my tiny cubicle, headset on, staring at the sales dashboard. I was still three sales short of my weekly target, and there was only an hour left in my shift. If I didn’t hit the number, my manager would be on my case again, and my bonus would slip away. I could almost hear her voice: “We need you to deliver, or we all fall behind.” My hands shook as I weighed the phone in my palm, torn between the desperate plea of my friend and the relentless pressure of my job. The clock ticked louder, and my heart pounded as I tried to figure out what to do.
